topic.title: HTML Introduction & Web Basics
topic.description: A beginner's guide to HTML, how the web works, and the roles of HTML, CSS, and JavaScript.

content.text: What is HTML and Why Does It Matter?

text.value: HTML stands for
HyperText Markup Language
. It is the standard language used to create and structure content on the web. Every webpage you visit — from a news article to an e-commerce store — is built on an HTML foundation. Learn more at the
MDN HTML Docs

content.title: Key Idea
content.text: HTML provides structure and meaning. CSS handles appearance. JavaScript adds behavior. All three work together but each has a distinct, separate job.
How a Web Page Reaches Your Browser

items: You type a URL into the browser address bar.
The browser sends a DNS request to resolve the domain to an IP address.
The browser sends an HTTP or HTTPS request to the web server at that IP.
The server responds with an HTML file.
The browser parses the HTML and requests linked CSS, JS, and image files.
The browser renders the fully assembled page on your screen.

content.text: HTML, CSS, and JavaScript: Roles at a Glance

examples.title: Your First HTML Document
examples.description: This example shows the minimum valid structure every HTML page must have. Each line has a specific purpose and removing any of them produces a technically incomplete document. Understanding this skeleton first makes every other HTML concept easier to place.
examples.code_snippet:
Hello, World!

This is my first HTML page.
examples.output: Browser renders a page with a large bold heading 'Hello, World!' followed by the paragraph text. The tab title shows 'My First Page'.

examples.title: HTML, CSS, and JavaScript Working Together
examples.description: This example shows the three layers of a web page in action within a single file. The HTML defines a button and a message. The CSS makes them look polished. The JavaScript makes the button interactive. Each layer could be swapped or removed without breaking the others.
examples.code_snippet: Separation of Concerns Demo
examples.output: Page renders a centered heading, a blue button, and an empty paragraph. Clicking the button fills the paragraph with 'Hello from JavaScript!' in green text. The HTML, CSS, and JavaScript each handle their own layer independently.

text.value: When structuring any content intended for a web browser
When building the semantic foundation before adding CSS or JS
When creating documents that need to be indexed by search engines
Avoid HTML for native mobile apps; use Swift or Kotlin instead
Avoid HTML for data storage or server-side processing logic
Avoid writing HTML without a proper doctype declaration
Plain text has no structure, so browsers cannot identify headings, links, or sections.
Without HTML, there is no standard way to embed images, links, or media on a page.
HTML gives search engines and screen readers the structure they need to process content.

HTML is like the blueprint of a building. It defines which rooms exist and where walls go. CSS is the interior designer who decides colors and furniture. JavaScript is the electrician who makes the lights switch on and off. You need all three for a finished building, but each professional has a distinct job.

A web browser is like a translation service. HTML is a foreign-language manuscript. The browser reads it, translates the markup into visual elements, and presents the result on screen. The original HTML file stays unchanged behind the scenes.

The request-response cycle is like ordering from a restaurant. You (the browser) ask for a dish (a URL). The kitchen (the server) prepares it and sends it out. The dish arrives (HTML file) and you experience it (the rendered page). If extra ingredients are needed (CSS, JS, images), the kitchen sends those separately.

Skipping the DOCTYPE declaration: Without <!DOCTYPE html> at the top, browsers fall into 'quirks mode' and apply inconsistent rendering rules from the early web era, causing layout bugs that are difficult to diagnose.

Missing the lang attribute on html: The lang='en' attribute tells screen readers which language to use for pronunciation. Omitting it forces assistive tools to guess, leading to incorrect text-to-speech output for multilingual users.

Using CSS or JavaScript to fake structure: Styling a div to look like a heading does not make it a heading semantically. Search engines and screen readers rely on HTML tags for meaning, not visual appearance.

Mixing concerns in one file for production: Inline CSS and JavaScript inside HTML is fine for small experiments but creates unmaintainable code in real projects. Always separate HTML, CSS, and JS into their own files for anything beyond a demo.

Open any webpage and press Ctrl+U (or Cmd+U on Mac) to view its raw HTML source. Reading source code of sites you admire is one of the fastest ways to learn real-world HTML patterns used by professional teams.

Bookmark the MDN Web Docs at developer.mozilla.org as your primary HTML reference. It is maintained by browser vendors, always accurate, and covers every element and attribute with compatibility tables and live examples.

subtopics.title: What is HTML?
subtopics.description: HTML is the markup language that defines the structure and meaning of all web page content.

text.value: HTML stands for
HyperText Markup Language
. It uses
tags
wrapped in angle brackets to label and organize content. Browsers read these tags and render them as headings, paragraphs, links, images, and more. The full HTML specification is maintained by the
WHATWG
and
W3C

content.title: What HyperText Means
content.text: HyperText refers to text that links to other text or resources. This linking ability is what turns a collection of pages into the interconnected World Wide Web.

examples.title: HTML Tags, Elements, and Attributes
examples.description: This example shows the anatomy of an HTML element: opening tag, content, closing tag, and attributes. Understanding these four building blocks is enough to read and write any HTML on the web.
examples.code_snippet:
This is a paragraph. The browser wraps text automatically.

Visit MDN Web Docs
examples.output: Page renders: a paragraph of text, a clickable MDN link, a company logo image, a checked checkbox, a Submit button, a horizontal rule, and a line break. Each element is labeled in comments showing its structural parts.

text.value: An HTML tag is like a label on a package. The label does not change what is inside the box, but it tells the delivery system, the recipient, and every handler in between exactly what kind of item it is and how to treat it. A heading tag tells the browser: treat this text as a top-level title.

HTML is a markup language, not a programming language. It does not perform calculations or make decisions. It annotates content with meaning, the same way an editor marks up a manuscript with margin notes saying 'this is the title' or 'this is a footnote'.

Use the MDN HTML element reference at developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTML/Element to look up any tag. Each entry shows the element's purpose, valid attributes, browser compatibility, and live examples — far more reliable than memory alone.

subtopics.title: How the Web Works
subtopics.description: The web works through HTTP requests and responses exchanged between browsers, DNS, and servers.

text.value: When you enter a URL in your browser, it triggers a chain of events. The browser contacts a
DNS server
to convert the domain name into an IP address, then sends an
HTTP
or
HTTPS
request to the web server at that address. The server responds with an HTML file, which the browser parses and renders. Learn how this works in depth at
MDN: How the Web Works

rows: Types address into the browser bar
Domain name resolved to an IP address
Sends GET request to the server IP
Returns HTML file with status code 200
Fetches linked CSS, JS, and images
Parses HTML and paints the page on screen

examples.title: HTTP Status Codes in HTML Context
examples.description: This example shows how HTTP status codes affect what the browser renders and how developers handle them in HTML and JavaScript. Understanding status codes is essential for debugging blank pages, broken images, and failed form submissions.
examples.code_snippet:
Common HTTP Status Codes

If a linked image returns 404, the browser shows a broken image icon:
examples.output: Page renders the heading and a paragraph. The missing image shows a broken image icon with 'Product photo' as fallback alt text. The result div shows a status-specific message depending on the API response: a welcome message on 200, a login prompt on 401, or an error message on 404 and 500.

text.value: The browser-server relationship is like ordering food by phone. You (browser) call a restaurant (server) and place an order (HTTP request). The restaurant prepares the food (processes the request) and delivers it (HTTP response). If an ingredient is missing, you get an error message (404 or 500) instead of the dish.

DNS is the phone book of the internet. Domain names like google.com are human-friendly aliases. DNS translates them to numeric IP addresses like 142.250.190.46 that routers use to actually route the traffic. Without DNS you would need to memorize IP addresses instead of domain names.

Open browser DevTools and go to the Network tab, then refresh any webpage. Every HTTP request the browser makes is listed with its status code, response time, and file size. This is the fastest way to understand what actually happens when a page loads and to debug slow or broken resources.

subtopics.title: HTML, CSS & JavaScript: Separation of Concerns
subtopics.description: Separation of concerns keeps HTML structure, CSS presentation, and JS behavior in separate layers.

text.value: Separation of concerns is a core web development principle.
HTML
defines what content is.
CSS
defines how it looks.
JavaScript
defines how it behaves. Keeping these in separate files makes code easier to maintain, test, and hand off to teammates. Read the official
CSS specification
and
JavaScript reference
to understand each layer in depth.

content.title: Why It Matters
content.text: Mixing CSS and JS inside HTML files works in demos but creates unmaintainable code at scale. A designer can update a CSS file without touching HTML. A developer can update JS without breaking styles.

examples.title: Separation of Concerns: Wrong vs Right
examples.description: This example contrasts the wrong approach of mixing all three layers inside one HTML file with the correct approach of separating them. The output is identical but the correct version is maintainable, cacheable, and team-friendly.
examples.code_snippet:
Dashboard

Dashboard

Dashboard

/* styles.css: presentation only */ h1 { color: #2563eb; font-size: 2rem; } #saveBtn { background: #16a34a; color: white; padding: 0.5rem 1rem; border: none; border-radius: 6px; cursor: pointer; } // app.js: behavior only const btn = document.getElementById('saveBtn'); const msg = document.getElementById('msg'); btn.addEventListener('click', () => { msg.textContent = 'Saved!'; });
examples.output: Both versions render identically: a blue heading, a green Save button, and an empty message paragraph. Clicking Save shows 'Saved!'. The right version allows a designer to update styles.css, a developer to update app.js, and a content writer to update index.html, all without interfering with each other.

text.value: Separation of concerns is like a restaurant kitchen. The chef (HTML) decides what dishes are on the menu. The plating team (CSS) decides how each dish looks on the plate. The waitstaff (JavaScript) handles interactions with the customer. If the chef starts plating dishes, or the waitstaff starts cooking, the kitchen breaks down. Each role exists for a reason.

External CSS and JS files are cached by the browser after the first visit. On every subsequent page load, the browser reuses the cached files instead of re-downloading them. Inline styles and scripts cannot be cached because they are embedded in a different HTML file on every page, multiplying the data each visitor downloads.

In modern frameworks like React, Vue, and Svelte, components appear to mix HTML, CSS, and JS in one file. This is still separation of concerns at the component level: each component owns its own structure, styles, and behavior as a self-contained unit. The principle scales from file-level to component-level separation.
